1.verse: Here begins the wonderful story of Jesus the Messiah, the Son of God.

2.verse: In the book written by the prophet Isaiah, God announced that he would send his Son to earth, and that a special messenger would arrive first to prepare the world for his coming.

3.verse: “This messenger will live out in the barren wilderness,” Isaiah said, “and will proclaim that everyone must straighten out his life to be ready for the Lord’s arrival.”*

4.verse: This messenger was John the Baptist. He lived in the wilderness and taught that all should be baptized as a public announcement of their decision to turn their backs on sin, so that God could forgive them.

5.verse: People from Jerusalem and from all over Judea traveled out into the Judean wastelands to see and hear John, and when they confessed their sins, he baptized them in the Jordan River.

6.verse: His clothes were woven from camel’s hair and he wore a leather belt; locusts and wild honey were his food.

7.verse: Here is a sample of his preaching: “Someone is coming soon who is far greater than I am, so much greater that I am not even worthy to be his slave.

8.verse: I baptize you with water but he will baptize you with God’s Holy Spirit!”*

9.verse: Then one day Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee, and was baptized by John there in the Jordan River.

10.verse: The moment Jesus came up out of the water, he saw the heavens open and the Holy Spirit in the form of a dove descending on him,

11.verse: and a voice from heaven said, “You are my beloved Son; you are my Delight.”

12.verse: Immediately the Holy Spirit urged Jesus into the desert. There, for forty days, alone except for desert animals, he was subjected to Satan’s temptations to sin. And afterwards the angels came and cared for him.

13.verse: Immediately the Holy Spirit urged Jesus into the desert. There, for forty days, alone except for desert animals, he was subjected to Satan’s temptations to sin. And afterwards the angels came and cared for him.

14.verse: Later on, after John was arrested by King Herod, Jesus went to Galilee to preach God’s Good News.

15.verse: “At last the time has come!” he announced. “God’s Kingdom is near! Turn from your sins and act on this glorious news!”

16.verse: One day as Jesus was walking along the shores of the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew fishing with nets, for they were commercial fishermen.

17.verse: Jesus called out to them, “Come, follow me! And I will make you fishermen for the souls of men!”

18.verse: At once they left their nets and went along with him.

19.verse: A little farther up the beach, he saw Zebedee’s sons, James and John, in a boat mending their nets.

20.verse: He called them too, and immediately they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired men and went with him.

21.verse: Jesus and his companions now arrived at the town of Capernaum and on Saturday morning went into the Jewish place of worship—the synagogue—where he preached.

22.verse: The congregation was surprised at his sermon because he spoke as an authority and didn’t try to prove his points by quoting others—quite unlike what they were used to hearing!

23.verse: A man possessed by a demon was present and began shouting,

24.verse: “Why are you bothering us, Jesus of Nazareth—have you come to destroy us demons? I know who you are—the holy Son of God!”

25.verse: Jesus curtly commanded the demon to say no more and to come out of the man.

26.verse: At that the evil spirit screamed and convulsed the man violently and left him.

27.verse: Amazement gripped the audience and they began discussing what had happened. “What sort of new religion is this?” they asked excitedly. “Why, even evil spirits obey his orders!”

28.verse: The news of what he had done spread quickly through that entire area of Galilee.

29.verse: Then, leaving the synagogue, he and his disciples went over to Simon and Andrew’s home, where they found Simon’s mother-in-law sick in bed with a high fever. They told Jesus about her right away.

5.verse: When Jesus saw how strongly they believed that he would help, Jesus said to the sick man, “Son, your sins are forgiven!”

8.verse: Jesus could read their minds and said to them at once, “Why does this bother you?

13.verse: Then Jesus went out to the seashore again and preached to the crowds that gathered around him.

14.verse: As he was walking up the beach he saw Levi, the son of Alphaeus, sitting at his tax collection booth. “Come with me,” Jesus told him. “Come be my disciple.” And Levi jumped to his feet and went along.

15.verse: That night Levi invited his fellow tax collectors and many other notorious sinners to be his dinner guests so that they could meet Jesus and his disciples. (There were many men of this type among the crowds that followed him.)

16.verse: But when some of the Jewish religious leaders saw him eating with these men of ill repute, they said to his disciples, “How can he stand it, to eat with such scum?”

17.verse: When Jesus heard what they were saying, he told them, “Sick people need the doctor, not healthy ones! I haven’t come to tell good people to repent, but the bad ones.”

18.verse: John’s disciples and the Jewish leaders sometimes fasted, that is, went without food as part of their religion. One day some people came to Jesus and asked why his disciples didn’t do this too.

19.verse: Jesus replied, “Do friends of the bridegroom refuse to eat at the wedding feast? Should they be sad while he is with them?

20.verse: But some day he will be taken away from them, and then they will mourn.

21.verse: Besides, going without food is part of the old way of doing things. It is like patching an old garment with unshrunk cloth! What happens? The patch pulls away and leaves the hole worse than before.

22.verse: You know better than to put new wine into old wineskins. They would burst. The wine would be spilled out and the wineskins ruined. New wine needs fresh wineskins.”

23.verse: Another time, on a Sabbath day as Jesus and his disciples were walking through the fields, the disciples were breaking off heads of wheat and eating the grain.

24.verse: Some of the Jewish religious leaders said to Jesus, “They shouldn’t be doing that! It’s against our laws to work by harvesting grain on the Sabbath.”

25.verse: But Jesus replied, “Didn’t you ever hear about the time King David and his companions were hungry, and he went into the house of God—Abiathar was high priest then—and they ate the special bread only priests were allowed to eat? That was against the law too.

1.verse: While in Capernaum Jesus went over to the synagogue again, and noticed a man there with a deformed hand.

2.verse: Since it was the Sabbath, Jesus’ enemies watched him closely. Would he heal the man’s hand? If he did, they planned to arrest him!

3.verse: Jesus asked the man to come and stand in front of the congregation.

4.verse: Then turning to his enemies he asked, “Is it all right to do kind deeds on Sabbath days? Or is this a day for doing harm? Is it a day to save lives or to destroy them?” But they wouldn’t answer him.

5.verse: Looking around at them angrily, for he was deeply disturbed by their indifference to human need, he said to the man, “Reach out your hand.” He did, and instantly his hand was healed!

6.verse: At once the Pharisees went away and met with the Herodians* to discuss plans for killing Jesus.

20.verse: When he returned to the house where he was staying, the crowds began to gather again, and soon it was so full of visitors that he couldn’t even find time to eat.

21.verse: When his friends heard what was happening, they came to try to take him home with them. “He’s out of his mind,” they said.

22.verse: But the Jewish teachers of religion who had arrived from Jerusalem said, “His trouble is that he’s possessed by Satan, king of demons. That’s why demons obey him.”

23.verse: Jesus summoned these men and asked them (using proverbs they all understood), “How can Satan cast out Satan?

4.verse: some of it fell on a path, and the birds came and picked it off the hard ground and ate it.

35.verse: As evening fell, Jesus said to his disciples, “Let’s cross to the other side of the lake.”

36.verse: So they took him just as he was and started out, leaving the crowds behind (though other boats followed).

37.verse: But soon a terrible storm arose. High waves began to break into the boat until it was nearly full of water and about to sink.

38.verse: Jesus was asleep at the back of the boat with his head on a cushion. Frantically they wakened him, shouting, “Teacher, don’t you even care that we are all about to drown?”

39.verse: Then he rebuked the wind and said to the sea, “Quiet down!” And the wind fell, and there was a great calm!

40.verse: And he asked them, “Why were you so fearful? Don’t you even yet have confidence in me?”

41.verse: And they were filled with awe and said among themselves, “Who is this man, that even the winds and seas obey him?”

15.verse: And a large crowd soon gathered where Jesus was; but as they saw the man sitting there, fully clothed and perfectly sane, they were frightened.

16.verse: Those who saw what happened were telling everyone about it,

17.verse: and the crowd began pleading with Jesus to go away and leave them alone!

18.verse: So he got back into the boat. The man who had been possessed by the demons begged Jesus to let him go along.

19.verse: But Jesus said no. “Go home to your friends,” he told him, “and tell them what wonderful things God has done for you; and how merciful he has been.”

20.verse: So the man started off to visit the Ten Towns of that region and began to tell everyone about the great things Jesus had done for him; and they were awestruck by his story.

21.verse: When Jesus had gone across by boat to the other side of the lake, a vast crowd gathered around him on the shore.

22.verse: The leader of the local synagogue, whose name was Jairus, came and fell down before him,

23.verse: pleading with him to heal his little daughter. “She is at the point of death,” he said in desperation. “Please come and place your hands on her and make her live.”

24.verse: Jesus went with him, and the crowd thronged behind.

25.verse: In the crowd was a woman who had been sick for twelve years with a hemorrhage.

26.verse: She had suffered much from many doctors through the years and had become poor from paying them, and was no better but, in fact, was worse.

27.verse: She had heard all about the wonderful miracles Jesus did, and that is why she came up behind him through the crowd and touched his clothes.

28.verse: For she thought to herself, “If I can just touch his clothing, I will be healed.”

29.verse: And sure enough, as soon as she had touched him, the bleeding stopped and she knew she was well!

30.verse: Jesus realized at once that healing power had gone out from him, so he turned around in the crowd and asked, “Who touched my clothes?”

31.verse: His disciples said to him, “All this crowd pressing around you, and you ask who touched you?”

32.verse: But he kept on looking around to see who it was who had done it.

33.verse: Then the frightened woman, trembling at the realization of what had happened to her, came and fell at his feet and told him what she had done.

34.verse: And he said to her, “Daughter, your faith has made you well; go in peace, healed of your disease.”

35.verse: While he was still talking to her, messengers arrived from Jairus’s home with the news that it was too late—his daughter was dead and there was no point in Jesus’ coming now.

36.verse: But Jesus ignored their comments and said to Jairus, “Don’t be afraid. Just trust me.”

37.verse: Then Jesus halted the crowd and wouldn’t let anyone go on with him to Jairus’s home except Peter and James and John.

38.verse: When they arrived, Jesus saw that all was in great confusion, with unrestrained weeping and wailing.

14.verse: King Herod soon heard about Jesus, for his miracles were talked about everywhere. The king thought Jesus was John the Baptist come back to life again. So the people were saying, “No wonder he can do such miracles.”

15.verse: Others thought Jesus was Elijah the ancient prophet, now returned to life again; still others claimed he was a new prophet like the great ones of the past.

16.verse: “No,” Herod said, “it is John, the man I beheaded. He has come back from the dead.”

17.verse: For Herod had sent soldiers to arrest and imprison John because he kept saying it was wrong for the king to marry Herodias, his brother Philip’s wife.

19.verse: Herodias wanted John killed in revenge, but without Herod’s approval she was powerless.

20.verse: And Herod respected John, knowing that he was a good and holy man, and so he kept him under his protection. Herod was disturbed whenever he talked with John, but even so he liked to listen to him.

21.verse: Herodias’s chance finally came. It was Herod’s birthday and he gave a stag party for his palace aides, army officers, and the leading citizens of Galilee.

22.verse: Then Herodias’s daughter came in and danced before them and greatly pleased them all. “Ask me for anything you like,” the king vowed, “even half of my kingdom, and I will give it to you!”

23.verse: Then Herodias’s daughter came in and danced before them and greatly pleased them all. “Ask me for anything you like,” the king vowed, “even half of my kingdom, and I will give it to you!”

24.verse: She went out and consulted her mother, who told her, “Ask for John the Baptist’s head!”

25.verse: So she hurried back to the king and told him, “I want the head of John the Baptist—right now—on a tray!”

26.verse: Then the king was sorry, but he was embarrassed to break his oath in front of his guests.

27.verse: So he sent one of his bodyguards to the prison to cut off John’s head and bring it to him. The soldier killed John in the prison,

28.verse: and brought back his head on a tray, and gave it to the girl and she took it to her mother.

29.verse: When John’s disciples heard what had happened, they came for his body and buried it in a tomb.

30.verse: The apostles now returned to Jesus from their tour and told him all they had done and what they had said to the people they visited.

31.verse: Then Jesus suggested, “Let’s get away from the crowds for a while and rest.” For so many people were coming and going that they scarcely had time to eat.

32.verse: So they left by boat for a quieter spot.

33.verse: But many people saw them leaving and ran on ahead along the shore and met them as they landed.

34.verse: So the usual vast crowd was there as he stepped from the boat; and he had pity on them because they were like sheep without a shepherd, and he taught them many things they needed to know.

35.verse: Late in the afternoon his disciples came to him and said, “Tell the people to go away to the nearby villages and farms and buy themselves some food, for there is nothing to eat here in this desolate spot, and it is getting late.”

36.verse: Late in the afternoon his disciples came to him and said, “Tell the people to go away to the nearby villages and farms and buy themselves some food, for there is nothing to eat here in this desolate spot, and it is getting late.”

37.verse: But Jesus said, “You feed them.” “With what?” they asked. “It would take a fortune to buy food for all this crowd!”

38.verse: “How much food do we have?” he asked. “Go and find out.” They came back to report that there were five loaves of bread and two fish.

39.verse: Then Jesus told the crowd to sit down, and soon colorful groups of fifty or a hundred each were sitting on the green grass.

40.verse: Then Jesus told the crowd to sit down, and soon colorful groups of fifty or a hundred each were sitting on the green grass.

41.verse: He took the five loaves and two fish and looking up to heaven, gave thanks for the food. Breaking the loaves into pieces, he gave some of the bread and fish to each disciple to place before the people.

42.verse: And the crowd ate until they could hold no more!

43.verse: There were about 5,000 men there for that meal, and afterwards twelve basketfuls of scraps were picked up off the grass!

44.verse: There were about 5,000 men there for that meal, and afterwards twelve basketfuls of scraps were picked up off the grass!

45.verse: Immediately after this Jesus instructed his disciples to get back into the boat and strike out across the lake to Bethsaida, where he would join them later. He himself would stay and tell the crowds good-bye and get them started home.

46.verse: Afterwards he went up into the hills to pray.

47.verse: During the night, as the disciples in their boat were out in the middle of the lake, and he was alone on land,

48.verse: he saw that they were in serious trouble, rowing hard and struggling against the wind and waves. About three o’clock in the morning he walked out to them on the water. He started past them,

49.verse: but when they saw something walking along beside them, they screamed in terror, thinking it was a ghost,

50.verse: for they all saw him. But he spoke to them at once. “It’s all right,” he said. “It is I! Don’t be afraid.”

51.verse: Then he climbed into the boat and the wind stopped! They just sat there, unable to take it in!

52.verse: For they still didn’t realize who he was, even after the miracle the evening before! For they didn’t want to believe!

53.verse: When they arrived at Gennesaret on the other side of the lake, they moored the boat

54.verse: and climbed out. The people standing around there recognized him at once,

55.verse: and ran throughout the whole area to spread the news of his arrival, and began carrying sick folks to him on mats and stretchers.

56.verse: Wherever he went—in villages and cities, and out on the farms—they laid the sick in the market plazas and streets, and begged him to let them at least touch the fringes of his clothes; and as many as touched him were healed.

1.verse: One day some Jewish religious leaders arrived from Jerusalem to investigate him,

2.verse: and noticed that some of his disciples failed to follow the usual Jewish rituals before eating.

3.verse: (For the Jews, especially the Pharisees, will never eat until they have sprinkled their arms to the elbows, as required by their ancient traditions.

4.verse: So when they come home from the market, they must always sprinkle themselves in this way before touching any food. This is but one of many examples of laws and regulations they have clung to for centuries, and still follow, such as their ceremony of cleansing for pots, pans, and dishes.)

5.verse: So the religious leaders asked him, “Why don’t your disciples follow our age-old customs? For they eat without first performing the washing ceremony.”

6.verse: Jesus replied, “You bunch of hypocrites! Isaiah the prophet described you very well when he said, ‘These people speak very prettily about the Lord but they have no love for him at all. Their worship is a farce, for they claim that God commands the people to obey their petty rules.’ How right Isaiah was!

Their worship is a farce, for they claim that God commands the people to obey their petty rules.’ How right Isaiah was!

8.verse: For you ignore God’s specific orders and substitute your own traditions.

9.verse: You are simply rejecting God’s laws and trampling them under your feet for the sake of tradition.

10.verse: “For instance, Moses gave you this law from God: ‘Honor your father and mother.’ And he said that anyone who speaks against his father or mother must die.

11.verse: But you say it is perfectly all right for a man to disregard his needy parents, telling them, ‘Sorry, I can’t help you! For I have given to God what I could have given to you.’

12.verse: And so you break the law of God in order to protect your man-made tradition. And this is only one example. There are many, many others.”

13.verse: And so you break the law of God in order to protect your man-made tradition. And this is only one example. There are many, many others.”

14.verse: Then Jesus called to the crowd to come and hear. “All of you listen,” he said, “and try to understand.

15.verse: Your souls aren’t harmed by what you eat, but by what you think and say!”*

16.verse: Your souls aren’t harmed by what you eat, but by what you think and say!”*

17.verse: Then he went into a house to get away from the crowds, and his disciples asked him what he meant by the statement he had just made.

18.verse: “Don’t you understand either?” he asked. “Can’t you see that what you eat won’t harm your soul?

19.verse: For food doesn’t come in contact with your heart, but only passes through the digestive system.” (By saying this he showed that every kind of food is kosher.)

20.verse: And then he added, “It is the thought-life that pollutes.

21.verse: For from within, out of men’s hearts, come evil thoughts of lust, theft, murder, adultery,

22.verse: wanting what belongs to others, wickedness, deceit, lewdness, envy, slander, pride, and all other folly.

23.verse: All these vile things come from within; they are what pollute you and make you unfit for God.”

24.verse: Then he left Galilee and went to the region of Tyre and Sidon, and tried to keep it a secret that he was there, but couldn’t. For as usual the news of his arrival spread fast.

25.verse: Right away a woman came to him whose little girl was possessed by a demon. She had heard about Jesus and now she came and fell at his feet,

26.verse: and pled with him to release her child from the demon’s control. (But she was Syrophoenician—a “despised Gentile”!)

27.verse: Jesus told her, “First I should help my own family—the Jews. It isn’t right to take the children’s food and throw it to the dogs.”

28.verse: She replied, “That’s true, sir, but even the puppies under the table are given some scraps from the children’s plates.”

29.verse: “Good!” he said. “You have answered well—so well that I have healed your little girl. Go on home, for the demon has left her!”

30.verse: And when she arrived home, her little girl was lying quietly in bed, and the demon was gone.

31.verse: From Tyre he went to Sidon, then back to the Sea of Galilee by way of the Ten Towns.

32.verse: A deaf man with a speech impediment was brought to him, and everyone begged Jesus to lay his hands on the man and heal him.

33.verse: Jesus led him away from the crowd and put his fingers into the man’s ears, then spat and touched the man’s tongue with the spittle.

34.verse: Then, looking up to heaven, he sighed and commanded, “Open!”

35.verse: Instantly the man could hear perfectly and speak plainly!

36.verse: Jesus told the crowd not to spread the news, but the more he forbade them, the more they made it known,

37.verse: for they were overcome with utter amazement. Again and again they said, “Everything he does is wonderful; he even corrects deafness and stammering!”

1.verse: One day about this time as another great crowd gathered, the people ran out of food again. Jesus called his disciples to discuss the situation. “I pity these people,” he said, “for they have been here three days and have nothing left to eat.

2.verse: One day about this time as another great crowd gathered, the people ran out of food again. Jesus called his disciples to discuss the situation. “I pity these people,” he said, “for they have been here three days and have nothing left to eat.

3.verse: And if I send them home without feeding them, they will faint along the road! For some of them have come a long distance.”

4.verse: “Are we supposed to find food for them here in the desert?” his disciples scoffed.

5.verse: “How many loaves of bread do you have?” he asked. “Seven,” they replied.

6.verse: So he told the crowd to sit down on the ground. Then he took the seven loaves, thanked God for them, broke them into pieces and passed them to his disciples; and the disciples placed them before the people.

7.verse: A few small fish were found, too, so Jesus also blessed these and told the disciples to serve them.

8.verse: And the whole crowd ate until they were full, and afterwards he sent them home. There were about 4,000 people in the crowd that day and when the scraps were picked up after the meal, there were seven very large basketfuls left over!

9.verse: And the whole crowd ate until they were full, and afterwards he sent them home. There were about 4,000 people in the crowd that day and when the scraps were picked up after the meal, there were seven very large basketfuls left over!

10.verse: Immediately after this he got into a boat with his disciples and came to the region of Dalmanutha.

11.verse: When the local Jewish leaders learned of his arrival, they came to argue with him. “Do a miracle for us,” they said. “Make something happen in the sky. Then we will believe in you.”

12.verse: He sighed deeply when he heard this and he said, “Certainly not. How many more miracles do you people need?”

13.verse: So he got back into the boat and left them, and crossed to the other side of the lake.

14.verse: But the disciples had forgotten to stock up on food before they left and had only one loaf of bread in the boat.

15.verse: As they were crossing, Jesus said to them very solemnly, “Beware of the yeast of King Herod and of the Pharisees.”

16.verse: “What does he mean?” the disciples asked each other. They finally decided that he must be talking about their forgetting to bring bread.

17.verse: Jesus realized what they were discussing and said, “No, that isn’t it at all! Can’t you understand? Are your hearts too hard to take it in?

18.verse: ‘Your eyes are to see with—why don’t you look? Why don’t you open your ears and listen?’ Don’t you remember anything at all?

19.verse: “What about the 5,000 men I fed with five loaves of bread? How many basketfuls of scraps did you pick up afterwards?” “Twelve,” they said.

20.verse: “And when I fed the 4,000 with seven loaves, how much was left?” “Seven basketfuls,” they said.

21.verse: “And yet you think I’m worried that we have no bread?”

22.verse: When they arrived at Bethsaida, some people brought a blind man to him and begged him to touch and heal him.

23.verse: Jesus took the blind man by the hand and led him out of the village, and spat upon his eyes, and laid his hands over them. “Can you see anything now?” Jesus asked him.

24.verse: The man looked around. “Yes!” he said, “I see men! But I can’t see them very clearly; they look like tree trunks walking around!”

25.verse: Then Jesus placed his hands over the man’s eyes again and as the man stared intently, his sight was completely restored, and he saw everything clearly, drinking in the sights around him.

26.verse: Jesus sent him home to his family. “Don’t even go back to the village first,” he said.

27.verse: Jesus and his disciples now left Galilee and went out to the villages of Caesarea Philippi. As they were walking along he asked them, “Who do the people think I am? What are they saying about me?”

28.verse: “Some of them think you are John the Baptist,” the disciples replied, “and others say you are Elijah or some other ancient prophet come back to life again.”

29.verse: Then he asked, “Who do you think I am?” Peter replied, “You are the Messiah.”

30.verse: But Jesus warned them not to tell anyone!

31.verse: Then he began to tell them about the terrible things he would suffer, and that he would be rejected by the elders and the chief priests and the other Jewish leaders—and be killed, and that he would rise again three days afterwards.

32.verse: He talked about it quite frankly with them, so Peter took him aside and chided him. “You shouldn’t say things like that,” he told Jesus.

33.verse: Jesus turned and looked at his disciples and then said to Peter very sternly, “Satan, get behind me! You are looking at this only from a human point of view and not from God’s.”

34.verse: Then he called his disciples and the crowds to come over and listen. “If any of you wants to be my follower,” he told them, “you must put aside your own pleasures and shoulder your cross, and follow me closely.

35.verse: If you insist on saving your life, you will lose it. Only those who throw away their lives for my sake and for the sake of the Good News will ever know what it means to really live.

36.verse: “And how does a man benefit if he gains the whole world and loses his soul in the process?

37.verse: For is anything worth more than his soul?

38.verse: And anyone who is ashamed of me and my message in these days of unbelief and sin, I, the Messiah, will be ashamed of him when I return in the glory of my Father, with the holy angels.”

1.verse: Jesus went on to say to his disciples, “Some of you who are standing here right now will live to see the Kingdom of God arrive in great power!”

2.verse: Six days later Jesus took Peter, James and John to the top of a mountain. No one else was there. Suddenly his face began to shine with glory,

3.verse: and his clothing became dazzling white, far more glorious than any earthly process could ever make it!

4.verse: Then Elijah and Moses appeared and began talking with Jesus!

5.verse: “Teacher, this is wonderful!” Peter exclaimed. “We will make three shelters here, one for each of you. . . . ”

6.verse: He said this just to be talking, for he didn’t know what else to say and they were all terribly frightened.

7.verse: But while he was still speaking these words, a cloud covered them, blotting out the sun, and a voice from the cloud said, “This is my beloved Son. Listen to him.”

8.verse: Then suddenly they looked around and Moses and Elijah were gone, and only Jesus was with them.

9.verse: As they descended the mountainside he told them never to mention what they had seen until after he had risen from the dead.

10.verse: So they kept it to themselves, but often talked about it, and wondered what he meant by “rising from the dead.”

11.verse: Now they began asking him about something the Jewish religious leaders often spoke of, that Elijah must return before the Messiah could come.

12.verse: Jesus agreed that Elijah must come first and prepare the way—and that he had, in fact, already come! And that he had been terribly mistreated, just as the prophets had predicted. Then Jesus asked them what the prophets could have been talking about when they predicted that the Messiah would suffer and be treated with utter contempt.

13.verse: Jesus agreed that Elijah must come first and prepare the way—and that he had, in fact, already come! And that he had been terribly mistreated, just as the prophets had predicted. Then Jesus asked them what the prophets could have been talking about when they predicted that the Messiah would suffer and be treated with utter contempt.

14.verse: At the bottom of the mountain they found a great crowd surrounding the other nine disciples, as some Jewish leaders argued with them.

15.verse: The crowd watched Jesus in awe as he came toward them, and then ran to greet him.

16.verse: “What’s all the argument about?” he asked.

17.verse: One of the men in the crowd spoke up and said, “Teacher, I brought my son for you to heal—he can’t talk because he is possessed by a demon.

18.verse: And whenever the demon is in control of him it dashes him to the ground and makes him foam at the mouth and grind his teeth and become rigid. So I begged your disciples to cast out the demon, but they couldn’t do it.”

19.verse: Jesus said to his disciples, “Oh, what tiny faith you have;* how much longer must I be with you until you believe? How much longer must I be patient with you? Bring the boy to me.”

20.verse: So they brought the boy, but when he saw Jesus, the demon convulsed the child horribly, and he fell to the ground writhing and foaming at the mouth.

21.verse: “How long has he been this way?” Jesus asked the father. And he replied, “Since he was very small,

22.verse: and the demon often makes him fall into the fire or into water to kill him. Oh, have mercy on us and do something if you can.”

23.verse: “If I can?” Jesus asked. “Anything is possible if you have faith.”

24.verse: The father instantly replied, “I do have faith; oh, help me to have more!”

25.verse: When Jesus saw the crowd was growing, he rebuked the demon. “O demon of deafness and dumbness,” he said, “I command you to come out of this child and enter him no more!”

26.verse: Then the demon screamed terribly and convulsed the boy again and left him; and the boy lay there limp and motionless, to all appearance dead. A murmur ran through the crowd—“He is dead.”

27.verse: But Jesus took him by the hand and helped him to his feet and he stood up and was all right!

28.verse: Afterwards, when Jesus was alone in the house with his disciples, they asked him, “Why couldn’t we cast that demon out?”

29.verse: Jesus replied, “Cases like this require prayer.”

30.verse: Leaving that region they traveled through Galilee where he tried to avoid all publicity in order to spend more time with his disciples, teaching them. He would say to them, “I, the Messiah, am going to be betrayed and killed and three days later I will return to life again.”

31.verse: Leaving that region they traveled through Galilee where he tried to avoid all publicity in order to spend more time with his disciples, teaching them. He would say to them, “I, the Messiah, am going to be betrayed and killed and three days later I will return to life again.”

32.verse: But they didn’t understand and were afraid to ask him what he meant.

33.verse: And so they arrived at Capernaum. When they were settled in the house where they were to stay, he asked them, “What were you discussing out on the road?”

34.verse: But they were ashamed to answer, for they had been arguing about which of them was the greatest!

35.verse: He sat down and called them around him and said, “Anyone wanting to be the greatest must be the least—the servant of all!”

36.verse: Then he placed a little child among them; and taking the child in his arms he said to them,

37.verse: “Anyone who welcomes a little child like this in my name is welcoming me, and anyone who welcomes me is welcoming my Father who sent me!”

38.verse: One of his disciples, John, told him one day, “Teacher, we saw a man using your name to cast out demons; but we told him not to, for he isn’t one of our group.”

39.verse: “Don’t forbid him!” Jesus said. “For no one doing miracles in my name will quickly turn against me.

40.verse: Anyone who isn’t against us is for us.

41.verse: If anyone so much as gives you a cup of water because you are Christ’s—I say this solemnly—he won’t lose his reward.

42.verse: But if someone causes one of these little ones who believe in me to lose faith—it would be better for that man if a huge millstone were tied around his neck and he were thrown into the sea.

43.verse: “If your hand does wrong, cut it off. Better live forever with one hand than be thrown into the unquenchable fires of hell with two!

44.verse: “If your hand does wrong, cut it off. Better live forever with one hand than be thrown into the unquenchable fires of hell with two!

45.verse: If your foot carries you toward evil, cut it off! Better be lame and live forever than have two feet that carry you to hell.

46.verse: If your foot carries you toward evil, cut it off! Better be lame and live forever than have two feet that carry you to hell.

47.verse: “And if your eye is sinful, gouge it out. Better enter the Kingdom of God half blind than have two eyes and see the fires of hell,

48.verse: where the worm never dies, and the fire never goes out—

49.verse: where all are salted with fire.

50.verse: “Good salt is worthless if it loses its saltiness; it can’t season anything. So don’t lose your flavor! Live in peace with each other.”

1.verse: Then he left Capernaum and went southward to the Judean borders and into the area east of the Jordan River. And as always there were the crowds; and as usual he taught them.

2.verse: Some Pharisees came and asked him, “Do you permit divorce?” Of course they were trying to trap him.

3.verse: “What did Moses say about divorce?” Jesus asked them.

4.verse: “He said it was all right,” they replied. “He said that all a man has to do is write his wife a letter of dismissal.”

5.verse: “And why did he say that?” Jesus asked. “I’ll tell you why—it was a concession to your hardhearted wickedness.

6.verse: But it certainly isn’t God’s way. For from the very first he made man and woman to be joined together permanently in marriage; therefore a man is to leave his father and mother,

7.verse: But it certainly isn’t God’s way. For from the very first he made man and woman to be joined together permanently in marriage; therefore a man is to leave his father and mother,

8.verse: and he and his wife are united so that they are no longer two, but one.

9.verse: And no man may separate what God has joined together.”

10.verse: Later, when he was alone with his disciples in the house, they brought up the subject again.

11.verse: He told them, “When a man divorces his wife to marry someone else, he commits adultery against her.

12.verse: And if a wife divorces her husband and remarries, she, too, commits adultery.”

13.verse: Once when some mothers were bringing their children to Jesus to bless them, the disciples shooed them away, telling them not to bother him.

14.verse: But when Jesus saw what was happening he was very much displeased with his disciples and said to them, “Let the children come to me, for the Kingdom of God belongs to such as they. Don’t send them away!

15.verse: I tell you as seriously as I know how that anyone who refuses to come to God as a little child will never be allowed into his Kingdom.”

16.verse: Then he took the children into his arms and placed his hands on their heads and he blessed them.

17.verse: As he was starting out on a trip, a man came running to him and knelt down and asked, “Good Teacher, what must I do to get to heaven?”

18.verse: “Why do you call me good?” Jesus asked. “Only God is truly good!

19.verse: But as for your question—you know the commandments: don’t kill, don’t commit adultery, don’t steal, don’t lie, don’t cheat, respect your father and mother.”

20.verse: “Teacher,” the man replied, “I’ve never once broken a single one of those laws.”

21.verse: Jesus felt genuine love for this man as he looked at him. “You lack only one thing,” he told him; “go and sell all you have and give the money to the poor—and you shall have treasure in heaven—and come, follow me.”

22.verse: Then the man’s face fell, and he went sadly away, for he was very rich.

23.verse: Jesus watched him go, then turned around and said to his disciples, “It’s almost impossible for the rich to get into the Kingdom of God!”

24.verse: This amazed them. So Jesus said it again: “Dear children, how hard it is for those who trust in riches to enter the Kingdom of God.

25.verse: It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God.”

26.verse: The disciples were incredulous! “Then who in the world can be saved, if not a rich man?” they asked.

27.verse: Jesus looked at them intently, then said, “Without God, it is utterly impossible. But with God everything is possible.”

28.verse: Then Peter began to mention all that he and the other disciples had left behind. “We’ve given up everything to follow you,” he said.

29.verse: And Jesus replied, “Let me assure you that no one has ever given up anything—home, brothers, sisters, mother, father, children, or property—for love of me and to tell others the Good News,

30.verse: who won’t be given back, a hundred times over, homes, brothers, sisters, mothers, children, and land—with persecutions! “All these will be his here on earth, and in the world to come he shall have eternal life.

31.verse: But many people who seem to be important now will be the least important then; and many who are considered least here shall be greatest there.”

32.verse: Now they were on the way to Jerusalem, and Jesus was walking along ahead; and as the disciples were following they were filled with terror and dread. Taking them aside, Jesus once more began describing all that was going to happen to him when they arrived at Jerusalem.

33.verse: “When we get there,” he told them, “I, the Messiah, will be arrested and taken before the chief priests and the Jewish leaders, who will sentence me to die and hand me over to the Romans to be killed.

34.verse: They will mock me and spit on me and flog me with their whips and kill me; but after three days I will come back to life again.”

35.verse: Then James and John, the sons of Zebedee, came over and spoke to him in a low voice. “Master,” they said, “we want you to do us a favor.”

37.verse: “We want to sit on the thrones next to yours in your Kingdom,” they said, “one at your right and the other at your left!”

38.verse: But Jesus answered, “You don’t know what you are asking! Are you able to drink from the bitter cup of sorrow I must drink from? Or to be baptized with the baptism of suffering I must be baptized with?”

39.verse: “Oh, yes,” they said, “we are!” And Jesus said, “You shall indeed drink from my cup and be baptized with my baptism,

40.verse: but I do not have the right to place you on thrones next to mine. Those appointments have already been made.”

41.verse: When the other disciples discovered what James and John had asked, they were very indignant.

42.verse: So Jesus called them to him and said, “As you know, the kings and great men of the earth lord it over the people;

43.verse: but among you it is different. Whoever wants to be great among you must be your servant.

44.verse: And whoever wants to be greatest of all must be the slave of all.

45.verse: For even I, the Messiah, am not here to be served, but to help others, and to give my life as a ransom for many.”

46.verse: And so they reached Jericho. Later, as they left town, a great crowd was following. Now it happened that a blind beggar named Bartimaeus (the son of Timaeus) was sitting beside the road as Jesus was going by.

47.verse: When Bartimaeus heard that Jesus from Nazareth was near, he began to shout out, “Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!”

48.verse: “Shut up!” some of the people yelled at him. But he only shouted the louder, again and again, “O Son of David, have mercy on me!”

49.verse: When Jesus heard him, he stopped there in the road and said, “Tell him to come here.” So they called the blind man. “You lucky fellow,” they said, “come on, he’s calling you!”

50.verse: Bartimaeus yanked off his old coat and flung it aside, jumped up and came to Jesus.

51.verse: “What do you want me to do for you?” Jesus asked. “O Teacher,” the blind man said, “I want to see!”

52.verse: And Jesus said to him, “All right, it’s done. Your faith has healed you.” And instantly the blind man could see and followed Jesus down the road!

1.verse: As they neared Bethphage and Bethany on the outskirts of Jerusalem and came to the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two of his disciples on ahead.

2.verse: “Go into that village over there,” he told them, “and just as you enter you will see a colt tied up that has never been ridden. Untie him and bring him here.

3.verse: And if anyone asks you what you are doing, just say, ‘Our Master needs him and will return him soon.’”

4.verse: Off went the two men and found the colt standing in the street, tied outside a house. As they were untying it, some who were standing there demanded, “What are you doing, untying that colt?”

5.verse: Off went the two men and found the colt standing in the street, tied outside a house. As they were untying it, some who were standing there demanded, “What are you doing, untying that colt?”

6.verse: So they said what Jesus had told them to, and then the men agreed.

2.verse: At grape-picking time he sent one of his men to collect his share of the crop.

3.verse: But the farmers beat up the man and sent him back empty-handed.

4.verse: “The owner then sent another of his men, who received the same treatment, only worse, for his head was seriously injured.

38.verse: Here are some of the other things he taught them at this time: “Beware of the teachers of religion! For they love to wear the robes of the rich and scholarly, and to have everyone bow to them as they walk through the markets.

2.verse: “But we can’t do it during the Passover,” they said, “or there will be a riot.”

11.verse: When the chief priests heard why he had come, they were excited and happy and promised him a reward. So he began looking for the right time and place to betray Jesus.

12.verse: On the first day of the Passover, the day the lambs were sacrificed, his disciples asked him where he wanted to go to eat the traditional Passover supper.

13.verse: He sent two of them into Jerusalem to make the arrangements. “As you are walking along,” he told them, “you will see a man coming toward you carrying a pot of water. Follow him.

14.verse: At the house he enters, tell the man in charge, ‘Our Master sent us to see the room you have ready for us, where we will eat the Passover supper this evening!’

15.verse: He will take you upstairs to a large room all set up. Prepare our supper there.”

16.verse: So the two disciples went on ahead into the city and found everything as Jesus had said, and prepared the Passover.

17.verse: In the evening Jesus arrived with the other disciples,

18.verse: and as they were sitting around the table eating, Jesus said, “I solemnly declare that one of you will betray me, one of you who is here eating with me.”

19.verse: A great sadness swept over them, and one by one they asked him, “Am I the one?”

20.verse: He replied, “It is one of you twelve eating with me now.

21.verse: I must die, as the prophets declared long ago; but, oh, the misery ahead for the man by whom I* am betrayed. Oh, that he had never been born!”

22.verse: As they were eating, Jesus took bread and asked God’s blessing on it and broke it in pieces and gave it to them and said, “Eat it—this is my body.”

23.verse: Then he took a cup of wine and gave thanks to God for it and gave it to them; and they all drank from it.

24.verse: And he said to them, “This is my blood, poured out for many, sealing the new agreement between God and man.

25.verse: I solemnly declare that I shall never again taste wine until the day I drink a different kind in the Kingdom of God.”

26.verse: Then they sang a hymn and went out to the Mount of Olives.

27.verse: “All of you will desert me,” Jesus told them, “for God has declared through the prophets, ‘I will kill the Shepherd, and the sheep will scatter.’

28.verse: But after I am raised to life again, I will go to Galilee and meet you there.”

29.verse: Peter said to him, “I will never desert you no matter what the others do!”

30.verse: “Peter,” Jesus said, “before the cock crows a second time tomorrow morning you will deny me three times.”

31.verse: “No!” Peter exploded. “Not even if I have to die with you! I’ll never deny you!” And all the others vowed the same.

32.verse: And now they came to an olive grove called the Garden of Gethsemane, and he instructed his disciples, “Sit here, while I go and pray.”

33.verse: He took Peter, James, and John with him and began to be filled with horror and deepest distress.

34.verse: And he said to them, “My soul is crushed by sorrow to the point of death; stay here and watch with me.”

35.verse: He went on a little farther and fell to the ground and prayed that if it were possible the awful hour awaiting him might never come.

36.verse: “Father, Father,” he said, “everything is possible for you. Take away this cup from me. Yet I want your will, not mine.”

37.verse: Then he returned to the three disciples and found them asleep. “Simon!” he said. “Asleep? Couldn’t you watch with me even one hour?

38.verse: Watch with me and pray lest the Tempter overpower you. For though the spirit is willing enough, the body is weak.”

39.verse: And he went away again and prayed, repeating his pleadings.

40.verse: Again he returned to them and found them sleeping, for they were very tired. And they didn’t know what to say.

41.verse: The third time when he returned to them he said, “Sleep on; get your rest! But no! The time for sleep has ended! Look! I am betrayed into the hands of wicked men.

42.verse: Come! Get up! We must go! Look! My betrayer is here!”

43.verse: And immediately, while he was still speaking, Judas (one of his disciples) arrived with a mob equipped with swords and clubs, sent out by the chief priests and other Jewish leaders.

44.verse: Judas had told them, “You will know which one to arrest when I go over and greet him. Then you can take him easily.”

45.verse: So as soon as they arrived he walked up to Jesus. “Master!” he exclaimed, and embraced him with a great show of friendliness.

46.verse: Then the mob arrested Jesus and held him fast.

47.verse: But someone pulled a sword and slashed at the high priest’s servant, cutting off his ear.

48.verse: Jesus asked them, “Am I some dangerous robber, that you come like this, armed to the teeth to capture me?

49.verse: Why didn’t you arrest me in the Temple? I was there teaching every day. But these things are happening to fulfill the prophecies about me.”

50.verse: Meanwhile, all his disciples had fled.

51.verse: There was, however, a young man following along behind, clothed only in a linen nightshirt. When the mob tried to grab him, he escaped, though his clothes were torn off in the process, so that he ran away completely naked.

33.verse: About noon, darkness fell across the entire land, lasting until three o’clock that afternoon.

34.verse: Then Jesus called out with a loud voice, “Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani?” (“My God, my God, why have you deserted me?”)

35.verse: Some of the people standing there thought he was calling for the prophet Elijah.

36.verse: So one man ran and got a sponge and filled it with sour wine and held it up to him on a stick. “Let’s see if Elijah will come and take him down!” he said.

37.verse: Then Jesus uttered another loud cry and dismissed his spirit.

38.verse: And the curtain in the Temple was split apart from top to bottom.

39.verse: When the Roman officer standing beside his cross saw how he dismissed his spirit, he exclaimed, “Truly, this was the Son of God!”

40.verse: Some women were there watching from a distance—Mary Magdalene, Mary (the mother of James the Younger and of Joses), Salome, and others.

41.verse: They and many other Galilean women who were his followers had ministered to him when he was up in Galilee, and had come with him to Jerusalem.

42.verse: This all happened the day before the Sabbath. Late that afternoon Joseph from Arimathea, an honored member of the Jewish Supreme Court (who personally was eagerly expecting the arrival of God’s Kingdom), gathered his courage and went to Pilate and asked for Jesus’ body.

43.verse: This all happened the day before the Sabbath. Late that afternoon Joseph from Arimathea, an honored member of the Jewish Supreme Court (who personally was eagerly expecting the arrival of God’s Kingdom), gathered his courage and went to Pilate and asked for Jesus’ body.

44.verse: Pilate couldn’t believe that Jesus was already dead so he called for the Roman officer in charge and asked him.

45.verse: The officer confirmed the fact, and Pilate told Joseph he could have the body.

46.verse: Joseph bought a long sheet of linen cloth and, taking Jesus’ body down from the cross, wound it in the cloth and laid it in a rock-hewn tomb, and rolled a stone in front of the entrance.

47.verse: (Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses were watching as Jesus was laid away.)

1.verse: The next evening, when the Sabbath ended, Mary Magdalene and Salome and Mary the mother of James went out and purchased embalming spices. Early the following morning, just at sunrise, they carried them out to the tomb.

2.verse: The next evening, when the Sabbath ended, Mary Magdalene and Salome and Mary the mother of James went out and purchased embalming spices. Early the following morning, just at sunrise, they carried them out to the tomb.

3.verse: On the way they were discussing how they could ever roll aside the huge stone from the entrance.

4.verse: But when they arrived they looked up and saw that the stone—a very heavy one—was already moved away and the entrance was open!

5.verse: So they entered the tomb—and there on the right sat a young man clothed in white. The women were startled,

6.verse: but the angel said, “Don’t be so surprised. Aren’t you looking for Jesus, the Nazarene who was crucified? He isn’t here! He has come back to life! Look, that’s where his body was lying.

7.verse: Now go and give this message to his disciples including Peter: “‘Jesus is going ahead of you to Galilee. You will see him there, just as he told you before he died!’”

8.verse: The women fled from the tomb, trembling and bewildered, too frightened to talk.

9.verse: It was early on Sunday morning when Jesus came back to life, and the first person who saw him was Mary Magdalene—the woman from whom he had cast out seven demons.

10.verse: She found the disciples wet-eyed with grief and exclaimed that she had seen Jesus, and he was alive! But they didn’t believe her!

11.verse: She found the disciples wet-eyed with grief and exclaimed that she had seen Jesus, and he was alive! But they didn’t believe her!

12.verse: Later that day he appeared to two who were walking from Jerusalem into the country, but they didn’t recognize him at first because he had changed his appearance.

13.verse: When they finally realized who he was, they rushed back to Jerusalem to tell the others, but no one believed them.

14.verse: Still later he appeared to the eleven disciples as they were eating together. He rebuked them for their unbelief—their stubborn refusal to believe those who had seen him alive from the dead.

15.verse: And then he told them, “You are to go into all the world and preach the Good News to everyone, everywhere.

16.verse: Those who believe and are baptized will be saved. But those who refuse to believe will be condemned.

17.verse: “And those who believe shall use my authority to cast out demons, and they shall speak new languages.

18.verse: They will be able even to handle snakes with safety, and if they drink anything poisonous, it won’t hurt them; and they will be able to place their hands on the sick and heal them.”

19.verse: When the Lord Jesus had finished talking with them, he was taken up into heaven and sat down at God’s right hand.

20.verse: And the disciples went everywhere preaching, and the Lord was with them and confirmed what they said by the miracles that followed their messages.
